body:
Hello,

I am trying to make a script in grasshopper to calculate the photopic lux for a particular view point in the room. I am considering only artificial lighting for this research.



Purpose of research- To calculate various photopic lux as I change the distance between the lighting fixtures and the view point.



I have made the script and connected all grids to the analysis part but I am facing problem of calculating my results. I have attached screenshot of some part of the script and also my '.gh' file along with the discussion.



Thanks for any help!

replies.body:
Hi Anmol,



I think the geometry in your gh file is not internalized. Can you share the rhino file, and your IES file, as well?



Sarith

Hello,



Thanks for the reply! Below I have attached my rhino file and the IES file.



Thanks once again!

Hi Amol, A few things: 1. You should update your HB installation by using the Honeybee_update_honeybee component as the latest release contains some bug-fixes that Chris Mackey and I had made over the past month. 2. You need to specify a sky definition to make the simulation work. In your case it will be dark sky as you are only simulating electric light. 3. I am not sure you can visualize a single point with a mesh. (Maybe you can... Chris , Abraham, Mostapha or Anton can better answer that question). 4. Your simulation will be in meters. So, I think you should either resize your room (if your original dimensions are in feet) or increase the number of fixtures to get a decent illuminance level. 5. Honeybee calculates photopic illuminance by default. 6. I made your simulation work by pasting the contents of your ies file directly into a text panel and linking it to the _iesFilePath. You can also make it work by simply specifying the path directly (ie. something like c:\light.ies etc..). See the attached file. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/6yWgYSVs-J0KxpZwBs2kXgLfs4PISNODqqReDPNk2QI3q2wgMrJyYHshGafqET-tC8SWKklegZffM3ulaswv7Bacls4V4inX/106201660046PM.png)

Hi Amol and Sarith, You can analyze a single point but not visualize with a mesh (there is no mesh). I would try to attach a geometry to the point (sphere, for example), and color it according to the result. -A. [](http://api.ning.com:80/files/9Dz4T2phCGGeKfavRTFeRs3F5lYLZX6D6yS-3zHD3HiVjk4gBnC0IKQql2fJgoEeg88UtZKFwp8za*CdRxAkBPrAz6bPfutB/Capture.JPG)

Thanks for that idea! I usually end up just tagging text when there is a single point since I could not think of any other way to visualize it.



Sarith

Hello Abraham,



Thanks for the suggestion! I would try it by attaching the geometry and then colouring it.



Thanks!

Hello Abraham,



Can you please elaborate the idea of analyzing a single point? 



Thanks!

Hello Sarith Subramaniam,



Thank you sir for your tips and guidance. The file attached by you was also very helpful and it has solved a lot of my problems.



Thank you once agina for your suggestions and time!
